race.name: DIRTY FRENCH
race.tagline: Ohio's Appalachian suffer fest - 9,000 feet of vertical brutality in the heartland

prestige.explanation: Growing reputation as the hardest gravel race in the Midwest. Regional recognition is strong and expanding, but not yet nationally prominent or series-affiliated.

race_quality.explanation: Solid organization by Wheelhouse Bikes with appropriate aid stations and support for a self-supported format. Good execution without Life Time-level production value.

experience.explanation: The suffer fest creates a memorable experience - beautiful Appalachian scenery combined with relentless climbing produces stories worth telling. Riders remember this one.

community.explanation: Limited field creates intimate atmosphere with good camaraderie among participants. Regional gravel community is supportive, though not the legendary vibe of iconic events.

field_depth.explanation: Strong regional competitors attend but lacks national pro presence. No major series affiliation means elite riders generally absent. Competitive but not deep. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Good value for a challenging, well-organized regional event. Registration fees are reasonable for what you get - a suffer fest in beautiful country.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-200. Moderate total costs - affordable lodging in Chillicothe area, reasonable travel for Midwest residents. Easy driving distance from major Ohio cities keeps expenses manageable. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

length.explanation: 100 miles places this in substantial territory. Not ultra-distance but a full day of demanding riding through Ohio's toughest terrain. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: Mixed terrain with steep Appalachian gravel roads, technical descents, and challenging loose surfaces. Not extreme singletrack but demands respect and bike handling skills. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: 9,000+ feet of climbing in 100 miles is exceptional for the Midwest. Relentless punchy climbs through Appalachian foothills create leg-destroying accumulated vertical. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 73°F and lows of 54°F, with a 52% chance of rain on any given day. Ohio spring weather is a dice roll - temps in the 50s-70s with real potential for rain and mud. Not extreme but variable conditions keep riders guessing. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Low elevation throughout at roughly 700-1,200 feet above sea level. No altitude considerations - pure climbing difficulty without thin air complications. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

logistics.explanation: Chillicothe is accessible from Columbus (45 min) and Cincinnati (90 min). Regional airports nearby, modest hotel options available. Not remote but requires planning.

adventure.explanation: Ohio's Appalachian landscape delivers unexpected beauty - rolling hills, forests, and pastoral countryside that surprises riders expecting flat Midwest terrain. The suffering creates lasting memories.

distances.name: 100 Mile
distances.description: Extremely challenging through Ohio's Appalachian foothills

race.terrain: Appalachian foothills gravel - steep sustained climbs, technical terrain, challenging Ohio hill country
race.weather: Ohio spring - variable temperatures (50s-70s F), potential for rain and mud
uniqueCharacteristics: One of the hardest gravel races in the Midwest
Growing reputation as a suffer fest
Beautiful but brutal Ohio Appalachian landscape

final_verdict.one_liner: Ohio delivers 9,000 feet of legitimate gravel suffering without the pretension of mountain racing.
final_verdict.should_you_race: You need solid fitness for 100 miles and 9,000 feet—this isn't a beginner's ride. The rolling Midwest terrain means constant power output with no real recovery sections. Come prepared for variable weather and mechanical self-sufficiency. If you can handle a 6-8 hour suffer-fest without mountain views as motivation, this will test you properly.
final_verdict.alternatives: Unbound 200 gives you similar distance with more prestige and Kansas wind instead of Ohio hills. Mid South in Oklahoma delivers comparable elevation with better post-race atmosphere and more challenging gravel surfaces.

course_description.character: Dirty French borrows everything cruel from Ohio's rolling farm country and amplifies it through 9,000 feet of grinding climbs. This isn't manicured gravel—it's crushed limestone that turns to peanut butter when wet, farm roads that pitch up without warning, and long stretches where your GPS becomes your only friend. The Chillicothe region doesn't negotiate; it just keeps rolling upward until your legs forget what flat feels like.

suffering_zones.label: The Farm Road Maze
suffering_zones.desc: Unmarked intersections and deteriorating gravel through working farmland. Miss a turn here and you'll add miles you can't afford to lose.

suffering_zones.label: The Limestone Grinder
suffering_zones.desc: Sustained climbing on loose crushed stone that punishes every pedal stroke. Your tires will hunt for traction while the gradient slowly increases.

suffering_zones.label: The False Summit Sequence
suffering_zones.desc: Three consecutive climbs that each promise to be the last big effort. They're all lying to you, and the third one is the steepest.

suffering_zones.label: The Final Reckoning
suffering_zones.desc: When you think you're done climbing, Ohio serves up one more sustained grind. This is where undertrained riders discover their actual limits.

course_description.signature_challenge: Nine thousand feet of elevation over Ohio farm roads means you're climbing constantly, but never dramatically enough to justify walking. The gradient hovers in that cruel 6-8% range where you can't rest but can't power through either. By mile 70, every slight rise feels personal.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
